content.content: CONTACT Name: StableLab Delegate Address: stablelab.eth Governance tracking: Boardroom, Internal tracker Forum: Doo_StableLab Discord: Doo_StableLab#3219 Twitter: https://twitter.com/Stablelab Blog: https://www.stablelab.xyz/blog Languages: English, Spanish, German, Dutch, Romanian, Korean, Chinese ABOUT StableLab is a governance firm focused on professional delegation, DAO framework design and product development. We work with various projects, from the ones just starting their journey to decentralization to the most prominent DeFi protocols. Our systematic framework for DAOs covers governance methodologies, decentralized workforce, implementation, documentation, communication and community engagement. There is no one-size-fits-all approach, but we provide a framework of principles and tools we have developed throughout our experience. We scale DAOs sustainably. EXPERIENCE We are the leading professional delegate team with a track record across major DeFi protocols, including MakerDAO, Optimism, Aave, 1inch, Balancer, Element, InstaDapp, Hop and more. We pioneer delegation work through high governance standards, extensive research, hands-on expertise and the consistent use of a code of conduct. Pushing forward web3 and DeFi since 2018, StableLab’s co-founders previously spent 3.5 years at the Maker Foundation.  1600×900 162 KB  Governance delegates and roles currently (or previously held by StableLab). View all our proposals, votes and milestones at stablelab.xyz /governance. VALUES & CONDUCT A. VALUES - A.R.T.   Active: We participate in every aspect of the governance process, from creating and presenting proposals to providing feedback in the forums and actively voting.   Research: Our decisions are backed by a team of experienced researchers and PhDs.   Trust: We act unbiased and transparent, according to our code of conduct - driven by a strong set of ethics and values.   B. DELEGATE CONDUCT   Use values to guide actions.   Maintain impartiality and transparency in participation.   Rely on data, research and prior expertise for proposals and votes.   Apply battle-tested internal policies for consistency.   Consult with the team for quality outcomes.   Why MakerDAO From DeFi to RWA to DAO Governance, MakerDAO has been a pioneer, and we will continue to contribute to MakerDAO in active and various ways. DISCLOSURE Through our holding company, we have invested in multiple projects to advance growth and governance for them. See the full list here.  We contribute to various protocols’ governance, such as Optimism, Aave, 1inch, Balancer, and Element. See the full list here.  When applicable, we will disclose potential conflicts of interest in our rationale. WAIVER OF LIABILITY By delegating to StableLab, you acknowledge and agree that StableLab participates on a best efforts basis and StableLab will not be liable for any form of damages related to StableLab’s participation in governance. StableLab have read and agree to follow the Delegate Code of Conduct 3. 3

content.content: Adding to Tim’s points, how will you deal with the inevitable conflict of interests that arise given that you are compensated by Growth and are working to ensure their success?  Will you abstain from voting initiatives driven by Growth? I understand the excitement here, and you are a great community member for sure, but I feel a sense of unease seeing CU members also become delegates. It all feels a bit incestuous and that there are potential issues for “control” of the DAO. Tough to put my finger on it though I sense it could be an issue down the line. Imagine if Doo had the same number of MKR as El Pro and could essentially vote in what he (presumably Growth’s proxy) wanted. Not saying this shouldn’t go forward though we should be wary of this trend, if anything for the problem of a small group appearing to control or have outsized influence over the DAO.

content.content: Thank you for the follow up. I also got a detailed DM which both helped me to examine more. For now, I will change my vote to Yes as my concerns have been addressed. Here was my reasoning and concern for initial No. I, like many other community members, agree that expanding Dai supply is important and collateral onboarding is crucial. The demand for RWA collateral is growing and unfortunately, the backlog for different types of collateral application is increasing as well. However, I was concerned about:   A lack of KPI in Dai supply impact. So the question of whether there is a range or goal on how much more Dai or collateral types this expansion will be able to bring?   Potential redundancy. Especially regarding Collateral Program Manager, how would the team make sure his/her role doesn’t overlap with the Risk team’s role?   Regarding #1, without specific goals with numbers, I couldn’t assess the significant impact of this expansion. However, the DM helped to understand more about the effect in number terms and the assessment seemed fair. Regarding #2, After hearing the explanation, I agreed that it can help to coordinate with other Core Units rather than overlapping or competing. Once again, thank you for the quick response and also apology for my short reasoning, which might have come off as a bit rude. Will try to write in more details in the future.

The following point also made sense:    MIP40c3-SP61: Modify Core Unit Budget - Real-World Finance (RWF-001)   Given the scale of the proposed budget increase (7x Q4 RWF cash burn), eight figures annually including the 3-month upfront contingency payment, we believe the DAO should receive more detail and substantiation. Additionally, the milestones the proposal implies are very ambitious and Governance should be confident the team can execute should the proposal pass. An Ambitious Budget Requires a Structured and Coherent Plan The attached budget suggests, at ~$250K per transaction, that 24 deals in the next twelve months will be achieved. However, the proposal focuses on locking in the commitment from the DAO without showing the corresponding plan and pipeline that would deliver these transactions.   Ratification Poll for Modify GovAlpha Core Unit MKR Budget (MIP40c3-SP60) - March 14, 2022 Voted Yes Related Core Value: Pragmatic Conflict of Interest: N/A –Retroactive compensation for LongForWisdom is fair and deserved. MIP40c3-SP60: Modify GovAlpha Core Unit MKR Budget   Note that a primary difference in our incentive model is that contributors retain the right to their MKR vesting even after leaving the Core Unit. This is to ensure a smooth transition.   Ratification Poll for Onboard-Amend Keeper Network - Gelato Network (MIP63c4-SP3) - March 14, 2022 Voted Yes Related Core Value: Pragmatic Conflict of Interest: N/A –This should be No based on principle where for asking for additional budget, there should be clear explanation on how the increase helps the Maker protocol (or hurts the system if not funded). Also, should we expect all Keeper Networks to be paid similarly eventually? However, considering the team will likely clarify once asked, voted Yes for now. Edit: The response has been indeed posted and shared. Ratification Poll for Onboard-Amend Keeper Network - Keep3r Network (MIP63c4-SP2) - March 14, 2022 Voted Yes Related Core Value: Pragmatic Conflict of Interest: N/A –Requested no budget so allows the team to try whether it will be helpful. content.content: Delegate Thoughts: Although Delegate’s role is different from director, I found the following tweet quite interesting and here are some of my takes.   twitter.com    Xavier Helgesen 🌍📚🌳🇺🇦 @XavierHelgesen  As an entrepreneur, I have had amazing Board Members and terrible ones.   Then I became one. But there was no manual, so I made a lot of expensive mistakes.   After 1,000+ board meetings, I decided to write one.   Here’s Good Director/Bad Director:   5:14 PM - 2 Apr 2022           2.3K                340            "Good Director knows they only have two jobs:  Hire and compensate the right CEO. Approve the budget and strategic plan.  Bad Director thinks their main job is to provide good ideas. They think the board’s job is to micro-manage the CEO." Which can be translated as onboard and compensate the right CUs and approve the budget and strategic plan. "Good Director trusts the CEO completely until they don’t. Once they don’t, it is time to make a change. There’s no in between. Bad Director constantly tests and scrutinizes the CEO, making them feel insecure in their role and always on the brink of being fired." I am probably guilty of it. Will try to be less scrutinizing. "Good Director knows that management can only focus on 1-2 things at once. Bad Director forwards an article they read with the subject line: “Why Aren’t We Doing THIS?!?!”" Come to think of it, I think many of us make this mistake to CUs. "Good Director always remembers that they are a fiduciary of all shareholders. Bad Director looks at every decision as: “What is in it for my firm/pocketbook?”" Very true that delegates should make decisions that ultimately support the Maker system and MKR holders. Just thought it was interesting how it helped me to reflect on some of my mistakes.

content.content: Well done pizza !!

Voting Updates:  Adjust CRVV1ETHSTETH-A System Parameters - April 11, 2022 Voted Yes Related Core Value: Pragmatic Conflict of Interest: N/A -Similar to my thought on PPG - Open Market Committee Proposal - April 4, 2022, I trust the Risk team’s assessment. Ratification Poll for Governance Communications Core Unit, COM-001, Mandate Refresh (MIP39c2-SP30) - April 11, 2022 Voted No Related Core Value: Pragmatic Conflict of Interest: N/A –I am still against COM CU’s expansion to “Public Relations Support.” My detailed reasoning can be found here: MIP40c3-SP63: Modify Core Unit Budget, COM-001 - #28 by Doo_Nam Ratification Poll for Dissolution of Content Production, MKT-001, Multi-Sig Request (MIP47c3-SP1) - April 11, 2022 Voted Yes Related Core Value: Pragmatic Conflict of Interest: N/A -As MKT is offboarded, makes sense to dissolve it. Ratification Poll for Modify Protocol Engineering Core Unit Budget, PE-001 (MIP40c3-SP68) - April 11, 2022 Voted No Related Core Value: Pragmatic Conflict of Interest: N/A -Of course, PE CU is a critical CU but at the same time, the Maker community needs to think about whether such budget increase is justified. If not, we will have all the CUs asking for a raise in budget and frame it as needed for the system to grow, and brand those who oppose as going against growing the ecosystem. However, there’s diminishing marginal utility and the budget of the Maker protocol is limited. So is it justified? We see that the cost is largely driven by increase in additional hirings. The focus of the team being expanding on L2 and sidechains.    MIP40c3-SP68: Modify Protocol Engineering Core Unit Budget - (PE-001)   The biggest cost driver is due to the team choosing to increase headcount by 3, from 14 to 17.   I also have a high hope for Dai expansion in L2, sidechains, and other mainnets. However, the better question is without this increase, would there be significant opportunity cost to the Maker protocol. And at least from the forum post and discussion, I was unable to find such. Therefore, voting no for now. Ratification Poll for Add Data Insights Core Unit Budget (MIP40c3-SP64) - April 11, 2022 Voted No Related Core Value: Pragmatic Conflict of Interest: N/A -While it was great to see different CUs expressing how they worked and got benefit from using Data Insights CU, the opportunity cost of not raising budget depends on a strong assumption. For example, the main argument was that the team wouldn’t have enough resources to dedicate to RWA and L2 data. content.content: Delegate Thoughts: CEO of Airbnb Brian Chesky posted this interesting thread about how he turned his company around:  twitter.com    Brian Chesky @bchesky  Our Q1 results are in:  102M nights booked $1.5B revenue (70% Y/Y) $(19)M net loss  $229M Adjusted EBITDA  $1.2B free cash flow   2 years ago, our business dropped 80%, our IPO was put on hold, and some didn’t think we’d make it at all.   Here’s how we turned Airbnb around:   8:08 PM - 3 May 2022           5.4K                550            First few posts were interesting and even might be relevant for the Maker Protocol. “First, we simplified our business. We got back to our roots, prioritizing the everyday people who host their homes and offer experiences” -For Maker, the root or the core use is of course its vaults and also stablecoin Dai. And especially in terms of vaults, it has been increasingly difficult to compete as the bear market has pressured the protocol to lower stability fee. However, are there ways to make vaults more competitive via other ways also accessible? These might be questions we have to wonder more. “We cut the vast majority of our projects, shuttered our business units, and made the painful decision to do a layoff” -If it comes to such dire situation, it might be important to look at some of “experiments” that the protocol has been doing but with not much return yet. “We significantly improved our cost structure, decreasing our cost of revenue (merchant fees and servers), and tightly managed our fixed costs” -For Maker protocol, fixed cost has been overall rising and some such as company set ups or operations should be able to reviewed to be more efficient. “Next, we changed our approach to marketing. When travel stopped, we paused all performance marketing and shifted our focus to PR (there have been 1M+ stories written about Airbnb since then)” “By 2021, we started investing in brand marketing again, but reduced our overall marketing spend from 34% of our revenue in 2019 to 20% in 2021” -This part is interesting because I think it ironically still shows the importance of marketing and PR. However, it is indeed important to focus on marketing and PR that is effective. “In 2021, we completely overhauled our product as the world became more flexible. We made 150+ upgrades and improvements, including launching the “I’m Flexible” feature, which has been used more than 2 billion times” -What would it mean for the Maker protocol to be more flexible in the first place? I believe the protocol has become more flexible both in approach and executions. For example, D3M is much more capital efficient but it wouldn’t have passed or executed in the early phase of DAO. However, compared to many other protocols, Maker still is not so flexible in many ways (easy ways to have multiple collateral for one vault for example) and also quite expensive to use.

content.content: @wouter Beyond this, didn’t SES request budget increases in general? Few times last year? I think for this is agree to disagree

No, we have not requested budget increases more than once last year. The only one since the original proposal was in August, close to 10 months ago now. The third MIP40 submitted in December was a technical improvement to the wallet and auditing setup which did not include a budget change.    MIP40c3-SP55: Modify Core Unit Budget - Sustainable Ecosystem Scaling (SES-001)   This budget update MIP is submitted by SES as part of our effort to help standardizing budget implementations, and to pave the way for further automation in terms of payments, reporting and auditing. No changes were made to the total budget cap.   Actual spendings have always been much lower than the budget cap because the cap needed to support peak fluctuations in the incubation and grants programs which are less predictable than permanent contributor compensation.

content.content: Voting Updates: Decrease GUSD PSM Fee Out (tout) - January 16, 2023 Voted Yes Conflict of Interest: N/A -We believe this might be healthy balance to allow some GUSD to be reduced in the Maker ecosystem but not too erupt. Adjust the GUSD PSM Debt Ceiling - January 16, 2023 Voted 1st no change 2nd 100 million Conflict of Interest: N/A -This was a difficult topic to vote. We had to balance between risk, revenue for the protocol, as well as Maker’s relationship with different partners. It’s true that there’s risk increasing regarding Gemini and its related products. However, it also have been generating revenue for the protocol. By the nature of PSM, we understand that even if the community ends up voting it to debt ceiling of 0, it won’t reduce GUSD exposure to 0 overnight. It just means that no more GUSD can be converted to Dai. And that slowly Dai will be converted to GUSD to reduce the PSM amount. Therefore, in practice, putting it into 0 or even 100 won’t make a difference in critical time. Therefore, we have voted to maintain the current ceiling to lean toward the protocol continue to have the revenue. However, we are open to suggestions and might change our voting before the poll closes.

content.content: Hasu  Key Info Name: Hasu Delegate Address: mkr.hasufl.eth - 0xafaff1a605c373b43727136c995d21a7fcd08989 Delegate Page: Here Forum: @Hasu Discord: Hasu#0730 Meet Your Delegate Video: Here  Delegate Statement  About me  Many of you might know me from Twitter. I would describe myself as a first-principles thinker and investor with a decade+ time horizon on the Defi and crypto space. I currently lead Strategy at Flashbots and collaborate on research with Paradigm. I co-host the Uncommon Core podcast with Su Zhu. I’m a long-term MKR holder and supporter of MakerDAO and have been thinking and writing about the project for years   My values and initiatives  Solving MakerDAO’s principal-agent problem Organizations in general, but especially more flat ones like MakerDAO, tend to suffer from the principal-agent problem. Specifically, Maker’s workforce (the CUs) are agents who work on behalf of their principals (the MKR holders). However, in the absence of managerial oversight, these agents don’t share the same interests as their principals, and the principals have neither the necessary information nor incentives to intervene. For a good read on the topic, especially regarding DAOs, I recommend Prof. Andy Hall’s post. In the context of MakerDAO, this principal-agent problem materializes as follows:  CUs get to make their own budgets and set their own roadmaps without proper oversight; there is very little accountability to MKR holders, and offboarding CUs or even individual facilitators has been a struggle MKR holders are supposed to make very complex decisions they are neither equipped nor financially incentivized to make; as a result, CUs get virtually free reign over the protocol, and no one sets a high-level strategic roadmap for Maker as a whole  To combat these problems, MakerDAO has created the delegate system. While the existing delegate system makes some steps in the right direction (e.g., ability to delegate MKR at all), it fails at what is arguably the most critical piece: to address the principal-agent problem and align the incentives between MKR holders and their delegates. Today,  delegates get paid by the DAO based on vanity metrics (e.g. vote participation) not the quality of their decisions. The latter would require delegates to divide labor amongst themselves and become domain experts focused on a small part of the DAO (e.g., financials, marketing, RWA, operations, workforce, etc.) The potential salary for delegates is much too small to attract the talent we need in these key decision-making roles.  Hence I propose to create a system of executive delegates (or super delegates) who, on behalf of MKR holders, are in charge of  steering the DAO in the long-term and setting a coherent vision holding CUs accountable to MKR holders  These executive delegates would work for Maker full-time and are properly aligned with executive-level compensation and MKR grants/options. They are not necessarily the same as today’s delegates and can be voted in, e.g., on one-year terms and voted out anytime. It is impressive what Maker has achieved as a headless organization, but we are hitting the scaling limit of this approach. It is time to create an incentive system that will attract the best strategy and leadership talent in the industry to steer Maker for the long term.  Toward data-driven decision making One of the most important yet underrated and underexplored aspects of DAO governance is managing the treasury. Any DAO can be seen as a resource allocation problem yet decision-makers lack the right framework to even think about the problem, let alone the information to make good decisions. For example,  How much capital buffer do we need? Which CUs are profitable vs. unprofitable for the DAO? Should we burn MKR, print MKR, or do nothing at all? How much should we value future profits vs. profits we can make today? Should we raise a strategic investment round, and if yes, at what terms? Should we raise money in a fixed-rate debt offering? Should we use incentives to grow, and if yes, where?  In absence of a strong framework for treasury management, we are left to defer to our gut feeling, and we have not been doing a good job at it. As a starting point for discussion, @monetsupply and I have created such a framework for treasury management in Defi. In essence, we propose to run Maker with the goal of maximizing MKR holder value and putting each dollar of revenue to its best possible use. Applied to MakerDAO, our framework suggests we should  never rely on equity offerings to cover capital shortfalls (as we did in March 2020) but instead build a much bigger surplus buffer, minimum 5-10% of all DAI outstanding suspend all buybacks and dividend payments for the foreseeable future heavily invest in future growth, possibly by doing a debt offering explore the option of a strategic sale to incentive key ecosystem or growth partners  Of course, our framework is all but complete and many of the above questions need constant evaluation by trained professionals. To this end, I want to encourage the creation of a treasury CU that becomes the “financial brain” of MakerDAO and creates data-driven recommendations to executive delegates and other key decision-makers. I have since learned about the new Strategic Finance CU and from early conversations and evaluating their existing work, it seems that they could possibly play this role going forward.  Conflicts of Interest  I don’t have any investments or incentives that should impact my role as a delegate at the current time. MKR is one of my biggest holdings. I consider myself very strongly aligned with the long-term success of the project I have also read, and agree with, the Recognised Delegate Code of Conduct.

The proposal also suggests the creation of a treasury CU that becomes the “financial brain” of MakerDAO and creates data-driven recommendations to executive delegates and other key decision-makers. The post also includes a framework for treasury management in Defi and the potential conflicts of interest of the author.

content.content: I voted in favor of adding EVENTS-001 and expanding the budget PE-001. To illustrate why let me make a few general points.  There has been a persistent meme that Maker is unprofitable over the last weeks and needs to cut expenses and block CU budgets. That is (1) not true, we are on track to earn $50m over the next 12months, and (2) even if Maker were unprofitable, that would be totally normal at this stage of our growth trajectory. Yes, our capital buffer is too low, but we finally have to separate this from our operating budget. Our capital buffer should be deeply positive, and our operating budget deeply negative, with the delta coming from debt and token issuance. I believe this is the goldilocks zone for Maker. So Maker should be spending more money, not less. Marketing should be among the largest costs in any growth startup, if not the largest. Maker is currently spending almost nothing on marketing. That needs to change. Maker customers (both borrowers and savers) are very sticky, warranting us to spend money on their initial acquisition.

content.content: Single deal-negotiations I think that doing single-deal negotiations like ATDC and IPCL is a very bad use of time, very complex, nonrepetitive, and something that Maker shouldn’t do. Instead, we should focus on wholesale lending to other lenders and leave the distribution of credit to the wider (crypto) economy to them. I encourage the deprioritization of single-deal efforts going forward and you can expect me to vote against any such proposals accordingly. TrueFi D3M Following my view that Maker should be a wholesale lender, D3Ms are the future. The TrueFi proposal looks credible and should be explored as a priority.
